24.text: First in the spotlight tonight is the actress Lisa Maxwell.

33.text: The comedian Gary Delaney answers questions on

36.text: the zombie films of George Romero.

40.text: Next, the actor Simon Greenall on the D-Day landings.

48.text: And the BBC commentator Conor McNamara on Irish whiskey.

60.text: Hello and welcome to Celebrity Mastermind with me,

64.text: John Humphrys, and four people who have achieved a lot over the years.

69.text: And now, well, they could be putting it all at risk depending on how

73.text: they equip themselves in that black chair.

75.text: But they are doing it all for charity.

78.text: The rules are the same - 90 seconds of questions on their

80.text: specialist subject and then two minutes on general knowledge.

84.text: So let us ask our first contender to join us please.

103.text: Garland was born Frances Ethel Gumm in June 1922,

106.text: the youngest of three sisters. By what nickname was

109.text: she known early in her professional career?

- to start playing the lady herself?

683.text: So I'm playing her in the last two weeks of her life.

688.text: So I need to go home and actually read a bit more about her.

695.text: She is a proper bona fide legend. I think it was her vulnerability.

699.text: I think she wore her heart on her sleeve and when you see her perform,

703.text: you can see that she is actually giving you absolutely everything.

707.text:
- Which, you know, is no pressure.

711.text: She paid a price for it, didn't she?

713.text: She did. I mean, she was taking pep pills from the age of 12,

717.text:
- given to her by her mother.

- Age 12.

720.text: So that she could do the late nights in the theatre.

722.text: And then diet pills and so on.

725.text: I think, from everything I've read, she was only truly happy when

728.text: she was in front of an audience, which is kind of sad really.

730.text:
- Isn't it? Well, good luck with the role. 
- Thank you, John.
